title: Current-carrying wires - change force from B-field

content.question: A long straight wire carrying a current <math alttext="I sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> is placed in a magnetic field of strength <math alttext="B " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math> directed into the page, as shown. While in the magnetic field, the wire experiences a force <math alttext="F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> due to the magnetic field. The magnitude of the magnetic field is then increased to <math alttext="2 B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>B</mi></math>, while the current in the wire is decreased to <math alttext="the fraction I sub 0 over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. The wire experiences a new force <math alttext="F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> in this second scenario. Which of the following is equal to the ratio <math alttext="F sub 1 to F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
